greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Consider the runs of 1's in the binary representation of n, each of these runs being on the edge of the binary representation n and/or being bounded by 0's. a(n) = the length of the shortest such run of 1's in binary n.
link: Michael De Vlieger, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..16384
example: 19 in binary is 10011. The runs of 1's are as follows: (1)00(11). The shortest of these runs contains exactly one 1. So a(19) = 1.
mathematica: Array[Min@ Map[Length, Select[Split@ IntegerDigits[#, 2], First@ # == 1 &]] &, 105] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Oct 26 2017 *)
results.author: _Leroy Quet_, Sep 21 2008
